Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Wireless pill bottle with dose-time reminders and a monitoring system which prompt patients to take medication as directed
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve human health through improved medication taking. While medications can provide significant improvements to human health, they can only do so if taken properly. Many consumers however often fail to take their medications correctly. By providing health networks a simple, cost-effective approach to medication taking oversight, focused improvement in patient adherence will directly result in fewer hospitalizations, better sustained health and improved long-term outcomes. By moving the burden of adherence monitoring away from the patient, expensive yet effective interventional practices can be focused only on those patients who actually need help, when they need it. This will both reduce labor costs and improve revenue potential for outpatient-services health networks. The product is based upon a straightforward, electronic dose-reminder and monitor system to improve and encourage self-management of medication taking while being supported by data-directed healthcare interventions. The system?s wireless data transmission allows for real-time measurement and intervention using objective medication-taking information, a process that is currently unavailable to healthcare systems and will reduce the billions of dollars spent annually in avoidable hospitalizations due to poor medication taking.


The proposed project will focus on developing a complete, wireless, medication adherence and monitoring system. Non-adherence has been shown to lead to $100 billion in avoidable hospitalizations each year with an estimated total cost of non-adherence to be as high as $290 billion a year. Only 50% to 60% of patients adhere to their medication regimens as directed. Existing adherence systems are not solving the problem because they are expensive to implement, require unique equipment or communication technology, requires the patient to remember and input their adherence data, fails to provide actionable information in time to be useful and doesn't provide a long term view of patient adherence, amongst other factors. The project's research objectives are to fully develop the circuitry, data bridging device and programming system for a Bluetooth low energy based adherence monitoring system. The system components will then be tested in a commercial and at-home setting that will mimic real-world use and implementation. System performance and functional characteristics will be recorded and optimized. We anticipate that the completed project will provide for a fully functional, medication adherence system that can be implemented for both clinical study and commercial evaluation of patient medication taking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the development and testing of an integrated medication adherence monitoring system. The system is being developed by DoseCue, LLC, a small business focused on improving medication adherence. The product based on an electronic dose time reminder and monitor and patient-centric philosophy that improves and encourages self-management with objective adherence data, while being supported by data-directed health care system intervention.

The key outcomes of the Phase I project was to develop a programmable medication  adherence reminder and monitoring system that also detects and records patient dosing behavior and transmits that information to a central database for monitoring. The system provides a real-time dose recording pill bottle and a simple  communication bridge for transmitting the dosing information  to a database where it can be monitored, specifically to detect  poor adherence behavior. A desktop software package and programming base station allows for pharmacy programming and control of the DoseCue containers as well as managing patient, medication and account information. These four components provide a complete adherence monitoring system that is implemented by the health care network, and not the patient.

Non-adherence to medication regimens is a significant cause of both poor health outcomes for patients and higher spending on health interventions. Medicare calculates that 11% of all hospital admissions are due to non-adherence to medications. A NEJM study found that 89,000 pre-mature deaths could be prevented in the United States each year if patients took their blood pressure medication correctly. The Cochrane Collaboration states that only 50% to 60% of patients adhere to their medication regimens. A November 2006 study from the National Community Pharmacist Association found 49% of patients forgot to take a prescribed medication and 38% forgot whether they had taken a medication. It is estimated that non-adherence results in $100 to $300 billion in additional health spending every year.

Current methods of correcting non-adherence, called interventions, generally rely on changing or moderating the patient’s behaviors to encourage behavior change. But interventions that rely on behavior modification alone are expensive to maintain, have mixed results and are not sustainable after the intervention is withdrawn. Recent developments in electronic devices for improving adherence often require significant behavioral changes and generally require learning a new technology, which rely on patient action for success, potentially increasing patient frustration.

There are many existing adherence products on the market, but none of these systems offers a comprehensive solution to the adherence problem. They either offer the device side of the problem, providing adherence monitoring and measurement, or they offer the intervention side providing patient support, messaging and oversight. None has shown capable of spanning both. Typical dose-time reminder solutions require patients to place their pills into boxes, to program a new device or application, or learn a new record-keeping system. Many of these approaches have been in place for decades, yet none has increased mainstream medication adherence. And all of them are driven by and dependent upon the patient to make them work, which is the primary reason why most do not provide sustainable benefits.

DoseCue’s solution, conversely, requires no work on the part of the patient (as the system is implemented and managed by the health care network) is simple to understand, and is ready to use when patients are handed their prescriptions.
